topic.title: DITA WebHelp Publishing Solution strong points

body.p: Oxygen XML Editor's own user guide is generated from DITA XML content and published as WebHelp Responsive output:

I tried to compile below some strong points that the published WebHelp output obtained from DITA XML content has:
It's a pure HTML5+Javascript publishing solution without the need of any server side component.
The WebHelp output can be used both offline and online.
Compatible with all browser vendors:
Responsive layout, adjusts to screen size and can be used on a wide variety of devices (mobile devices, tablets or desktops).
The WebHelp layout can be fully customized: .
The WebHelp publishing comes with 7-8 pre-configuref color themes but you can create your own publishing templates: .
You can also use the free Oxygen Styles Basket web site to customize the WebHelp output: .
Contains its own search engine implemented in Javascript (with support for AND, OR, exact match, auto complete and highlights). The search engine can assign various weights and priorities to various elements.
Automatically generates an Index page if the DITA content contains index elements.
For each section contained inside a topic a mini table of contents is generated: .
Inner topics, sections and topics can be folded.
Code block contents can be automatically syntax highlighted when publishing: .
Track changes and comments made to the DITA XML content can be published as side notes in the WebHelp output..
The WebHelp output comes with support for the following built-in languages: English, French, German, Japanese, and Chinese. And support for additional languages can be further added. It can also be used with right-to-left text orientation:
It can be used for context sensitive help, called with various help IDs from an application:
The WebHelp Feedback system can be integrated in every WebHelp page and provides support for users to add comments and give feedback Feedback (create account, post message, moderate, manage multiple versions of documentation):
You can embed Facebook, Twitter, or Google Analytics: .
WebHelp documentation can also be produced on the server side:
The WebHelp output was tested for Accessibility problems, it works well with a screen narrator and one of the WebHelp color themes is fully 508 compliant for people with reduced vision:
